bylaws to govern conduct of business art 1 10217 editors note art 1 adopted oct 2 201 repealed the former  1854 and enacted a new section as set out herein the former  1854 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from   and art 3 adopted jan 8 1996 officers the board shall meet annually during the month of november to elect officers   art 13 4300 powers and duties a the board shall act in an advisory capacity to the city council to review promote and expedite development and use of city golf course facilities b the board may study any problem or condition relating to the construction operation maintenance or improvement of or addition to the golf course or related facilities the board may meet and confer with any individual partnership association corporation or local state or federal agent or governmental organization the board may present its findings and related recommendations to the city council c the board may make recommendations to the city council about scheduling of activities at the golf course and act in other respects as coordinator for public recreation at the golf course d the board shall keep the city council informed of its activities  golf course budget the board shall on or before the fifteenth day of april of each year submit to the city manager its recommendations for golf course development programs  reserved editors note of adopted  repealed  1858 golf course fees in its entirety former  1858 derived from  2038 of the  police footnotes  1  cross reference administration ch 2  civil defense ch 10  fire prevention and protection ch 11  municipal court ch 16  traffic ch 26  police department  253  enforcement of animal ordinance  65  private security patrol services  15361 et seq  traffic division  2621 et seq  enforcement of traffic regulations  2651 et seq state law reference police rsmo ch 85 et seq article i  in general chief of police  rules regulations the chief of police shall serve at the direction of the city manager and may be dismissed at will by the city manager the chief is authorized to issue regulations and general orders pertaining to the operation of the police department such regulations and general orders shall be in conformity with the charter and ordinances of the city and may be rescinded by the city manager  cross reference administration ch 2 police officer qualifications all members of the police department shall be at least twentyone 21 years of age and residents of the state police officers shall meet such other qualifications as may be established by the city manager or the chief of police  police officer powers any police officer shall have the power to arrest on view and without warrant any person he sees violating or who he has reasonable grounds to believe has violated any law of the state or any ordinance of the city police officers shall have the authority to respond to emergency situations outside the city limits police officers shall have all other powers necessary or incident to the performance of the police department function under authority set forth in rsmo the cape girardeau police department is hereby authorized to respond and provide assistance as requested in any mutual aid or emergency aid request   art 1 92192  art 1 4593 disposition of unclaimed or abandoned personal property sale a this section applies to personal property in the possession of the police department other than motor vehicles and weapons the owner of which is unknown and cannot be located efforts b the police chief shall make reasonable efforts to locate owners of personal property in the possession of the police department c the chief of police shall report to the city manager periodically on all unclaimed and abandoned personal property in possession of the police department and shall keep a current inventory of all such items when unclaimed and abandoned personal property has been in the possession of the police department for thirty 30 consecutive days it may be sold at public sale public sales shall be called from time to time as may be necessary by the police chief on authorization of the city manager there shall be a minimum of one 1 public sale per year with all proceeds going into the general revenue fund of the city d the public sale shall be held only after notice has been published for five 5 consecutive days in a newspaper of daily circulation  and shall be held at a public place designated by the police chief such notice shall include the date time and place of such sale but need not describe the property to be sold e individuals may reclaim personal property up to the time of sale by a reasonable showing of ownership to the police chief or his designee  disposition of firearms dangerous and deadly weapons a the police chief shall dispose of all unclaimed abandoned or forfeited firearms and dangerous and deadly weapons and all firearms and dangerous and deadly weapons turned in by individuals in the following manner 1 if the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon is of the type designated as regulation equipment for the police department then the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon may be utilized as police equipment 2 if the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon is of historical value or of an unusual nature the firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon may be placed in the police departments display case for exhibition purposes only 3 all other firearms or dangerous and deadly weapons shall either be destroyed in such a manner as to render them irreparable and buried at the citys landfill or disposed of in any other lawful manner b the chief of police shall report to the city manager periodically on all nonregulation firearms and dangerous and deadly weapons in the possession of the police department and shall in addition keep a current inventory of all such items c no firearm shall be considered to be unclaimed or abandoned unless the firearm is in the possession of the police department for thirty 30 consecutive days an individual may reclaim his firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon only upon a reasonable showing of ownership no firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon shall be returned to a convicted felon to a minor or any other individual not having a legal right to possession the thirtyconsecutiveday requirement shall not begin to apply to a specific firearm or dangerous and deadly weapon when the item is being held for evidence in a trial or other legal hearing but shall only begin to run when the trial or legal hearing and all other legal processes involved are completed  cross reference offenses involving weapons and explosives  1796 et seq secs 2062020  reserved article ii  police reserves footnotes  2  cross reference administration ch 2 power of appointment the city manager is authorized to appoint police reserve officers officers so appointed shall meet the qualifications and shall have the powers set forth in this article  qualifications and training a police reserve officers must be residents of the state twentyone 21 years of age or older b police reserve officers shall qualify in the use of firearms semiannually in accordance with standards established by the police department such officers may be required to participate in training programs sponsored and provided by the police department c recruitment and selection of police reserve officers shall be based on minimum standards developed by the chief of police and approved by the city manager d police reserve officers appointed after the effective date of must have successfully completed a course of basic training for peace officers in a program approved and accredited by the director of the state department of public safety  volunteer status members of the police reserve shall receive no compensation from the city for their services  police reserve officer powers police reserve officers who are on actual duty shall have the same powers as regular police officers  supervision the police reserve shall serve at the direction of the chief of police  rules and regulations the city manager and the chief of police may issue rules and regulations governing the police reserve  rank the city manager may authorize a rank structure for the police reserve police reserve officers regardless of rank shall be subordinate to regular police officers of any rank  dismissals the city manager may at any time and without prior notification or hearing terminate the membership of any person in the police reserve    reserved article iii  deputization of southeast missouri state university public safety officers power of appointment the city manager is authorized to appoint southeast missouri state university public safety officers as deputy city police officers officers so appointed shall meet the qualifications and shall have the powers set forth in this article  qualifications a southeast missouri state university public safety officers appointed as deputy city police officers must be state residents twentyone 21 years of age or older who have successfully completed a course of basic training for peace officers in a program approved and accredited by the director of the state department of public safety b southeast missouri state university public safety officers appointed as deputy city police officers shall qualify in the use of firearms semiannually in accordance with standards established by the police department such officers may be required to participate in training programs sponsored and provided by the police department c recruitment and selection of southeast missouri state university public safety officers to be deputized by the city as city police officers shall be based on minimum standards approved by the city manager  arrest power any southeast missouri state university public safety officer appointed as deputy city police officer shall have the power to arrest on view and without warrant any person he sees violating or who he has reasonable grounds to believe has violated any law of the state or any ordinance of the city  supervision southeast missouri state university public safety officers appointed as deputy city police officers shall be employees of southeast missouri state university and shall routinely receive direct supervision from their superiors in the southeast missouri state university department of public safety  rules and regulations the city manager and the chief of police may issue rules and regulations pertaining to deputy city police officers  revocation of deputization the city manager may at any time and without prior notification or hearing revoke the appointment of any southeast missouri state university public safety officer as a deputy city police officer except in extreme situations however the city manager shall exercise this power only after discussions with appropriate university officials  insurance a no southeast missouri state university public safety officer shall be appointed as deputy city police officer unless southeast missouri state university shall carry liability insurance to cover the activities of all public safety officers deputized by the city in the minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars $50000000 each person five hundred thousand dollars $50000000 each occurrence one million dollars $100000000 annual aggregate such insurance shall name the city and its officials and employees as insureds the city manager shall revoke the appointments of all southeast missouri state university public safety officers as deputy city police officers if such insurance is not provided at all times and evidence of such insurance provided to the city manager b southeast missouri state university shall not be required to meet the insurance requirements of subsection a of this section for such time as the conduct of its public safety officers arising out of and performed in connection with their official duties on behalf of the university are covered by the state legal expense fund created by rsmo   secs 20532070  reserved article iv  major case squad footnotes  3  editors note adopted dec 19 199 amended the 1967 adding ch 23 art iv  23502354 thereto the editor has included the new provisions as art iv  20712075 at his discretion established there is hereby established a major case squad and the city of cape girardeau police department is hereby authorized to cooperate with the cape girardeau county sheriffs department and prosecuting attorneys office the city of jackson missouris police department the bollinger county sheriffs department and prosecuting attorneys office the scott county sheriffs department and prosecuting attorneys office and the missouri state highway patrol in the formation of a major case squad for the purpose of intensive professional investigation of a certain individual crime which may occur in their general geographical area art 1 121990 expenses expenses of the major case squad may be paid by the individual political subdivisions forming the major case squad the payment of expenses by the city shall be subject to the direction of the city manager art 1 121990 activation the major case squad shall operate and be activated upon the request of the county sheriff or police chief of the political subdivision where the crime occurred art 1 121990 power of arrest whenever any peace officer is duly authorized as a member of a major case squad such officer shall have the power to arrest anywhere within this state this power shall only be exercised during the times the peace officer is an active member of an active major case squad and only within the scope of the investigation on which the squad is working art 1 121990 notice to other jurisdictions prior to the initiation of a major case squad investigation in a political subdivision other than where the crime occurred a member of the major case squad shall notify the chief law enforcement officer of the political subdivision in which the investigation is to be conducted or a designated agent thereof art 1 121990 public improvements and special assessments footnotes  1  cross reference streets and sidewalks ch 24  water and sewers ch 29 state law reference public improvements rsmo   et seq article i  in general secs 2112125  reserved article ii  land acquisition and public improvements acquisition of property interests the city shall have full power and authority to acquire interest in real estate for any public use by gift devise purchase lease dedication or the exercise of the power of eminent domain by condemnation proceedings a1 condemnation procedure except where otherwise provided by law the city in exercising the power of eminent domain shall follow the procedures set forth in the missouri supreme court rules a2 public improvements except where otherwise provided by law the construction of public improvements may be authorized by resolution of the city council a3 funding public improvements public improvements may be funded by any lawful method or combination of methods a4 secs 21302145  reserved article iii  special assessment projects governing law the procedure for levying collecting and enforcing the payment of special assessments for public improvements or special tax bills evidencing such assessments shall be governed by rsmo  and by the provisions of this article however the specific procedures for levying collecting and enforcing the payment of special assessments for water mains shall additionally be governed either by rsmo  or by creating a special assessment water district and using the procedure in rsmo  the choice of which special assessment procedure shall be used for water mains shall be left to the sole discretion of the city council or its designee a11  art 1 81897 advancement of city funds the city council may provide that the costs of any special assessment project be advanced from city funds and that the special tax bills issued thereafter be made payable to the city a12 street improvement projects  right of remonstrance the city council shall not impose special assessments in excess of fifty 50 percent of the total cost of any street improvement project exceeding twelve hundred 1200 feet in length where a valid written protest against the improvement has been filed with the city clerk within ten 10 days after the final publication required by rsmo  in order to be valid the protest must be signed by a majority of the owners of the abutting lands who reside within the city limits who would be liable for the cost of the improvement and who shall own a majority of the front feet abutting on the street or part of the street proposed to be improved art 123a13 82090 engineers estimate the city engineer shall prepare a cost estimate on every project for which a special assessment is to be levied under the terms of this article the city may not accept any bid for construction of that project which exceeds the engineers cost estimate unless all bids properly received exceeded that estimate in such a case the bid accepted by the city may exceed the engineers estimate by up to ten 10 percent of that estimate but only if that bid was the lowest bid received on that project art 1 91503 secs 21502165  reserved article iv  vacating city streets power to vacate the city council may by ordinance vacate any city street or any interest the city has in any real estate after first holding a public hearing as provided in this article and after finding that such vacation is in the public interest a34 public hearing the city council shall hold a public hearing to consider vacating a city street or the citys interest in any real estate whenever it receives a petition to vacate signed by each owner of property abutting the street sought to be vacated or abutting the property in which the citys interest is sought to be vacated the city council may on its own motion hold a hearing to consider vacating any city street or the citys interest in any real estate at least ten 10 days notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city all interested parties shall be afforded the opportunity at the hearing to speak in favor of or in opposition to the proposed vacation a35 solid waste and weeds footnotes  1  cross reference administration ch 2  fire prevention and protection ch 11  health and sanitation ch 13  licenses and business regulations ch 15  water and sewers ch 29  burning air pollution regulations  39 et seq  removal of dead animals  62  refuse handling in travel trailer camps and mobile home parks  2737  insect and rodent control in travel trailer camps and mobile home parks  2738 state law reference solid waste rsmo   et seq article i  in general secs 2212225  reserved article ii  storage collection transportation processing and disposal of solid waste definitions for the purposes of this article the following terms shall be deemed to have the meaning indicated below approved incinerator means an incinerator which complies with all current regulations of the missouri air conservation commission and the requirements of the city bulky rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible andor noncombustible waste materials from dwelling units commercial industrial institutional or agricultural establishments which are either too large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste collection vehicles by solid waste collectors with the equipment available therefor city staff means the public works department of the city collection means the removal and transportation of solid waste from its place of storage to its place of processing or disposal commercial establishment means any commercial industrial institutional or agricultural establishment and any multiple housing facility or multiple housing complex with more than three 3 dwelling units demolition and construction waste means waste materials from the construction or destruction of residential industrial or commercial structures disposal facility means solid waste transfer station landfill disposal site or any other approved site for the handling and disposition of solid waste disposable solid waste containers means disposable plastic sacks with a capacity of twenty 20 to thirtytwo 32 gallons specifically designed for storage of solid waste dumpster means any container receptacle compactor unit trailer rolloff or similar unit with or without wheels that is used for temporary storage containment or transport of refuse debris trash garbage food waste solid waste recyclable material incidental demolition debris or other discarded or like materials it shall not apply to ordinary household trash cans of a volume of sixtyfour 64 gallons or less recycling receptacles of ninetysix 96 gallons or less dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a structure and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or are intended to be used for living sleeping cooking and eating garbage means putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the handling preparation cooking serving or consumption of food hazardous wastes means and includes but is not limited to pathological wastes explosive wastes pesticides pesticide containers toxic or radioactive materials multiple housing complex means a group of multiple housing facilities under the same ownership and control located in the same and contiguous geographical area multiple housing facility means a housing facility containing more than one 1 dwelling unit under one 1 roof occupant means any person who alone or jointly or severally with others shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved real property either as owner or as tenant operating fee means costs incurred by the city for equipment and personnel to provide refuse service person means any individual partnership copartnership firm company corporation association joint stock company trust estate political subdivision or organization of any kind or their legal representatives agents or assigns processing means incinerating composting baling shredding salvaging compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced recyclables are items collected by recycling crews which have been deemed acceptable for recycling by the city staff recycling center means a facility for drop off and processing of recyclable products recycling containers are containers that provide for access separation and content identification for the collection of recyclable products refuse means solid waste solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state including but not limited to garbage ashes street refuse rubbish dead animals animal and agricultural wastes yard wastes discarded appliances special wastes industrial wastes and demolition and construction wastes 1 commercial solid waste solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial industrial institutional or agricultural establishment and any multiple housing facilities with more than three 3 dwelling units or multiple housing complexes with more than three 3 dwelling units 2 residential solid waste solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units excluding multiple housing facilities with more than three 3 dwelling units and multiple housing complexes with more than three 3 dwelling units solid waste containers means receptacles used by any person to store solid wastes during the interval between solid waste collections solid waste disposal means the process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material in particular the final disposition of solid waste by man solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage collection transportation processing and disposal storage means keeping maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection tipping fee means the per ton cost of operation of the transfer station and cost for transportation and disposal yard waste includes all grass clippings leaves yard and garden vegetation tree limbs and brush    21589  arts 1 2 61890  arts 1 2 71690   2 61592  art 1 32017 city to provide containers the city shall provide each residential solid waste customer with one 1 sixtyfour 64 gallon container for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish demolition and construction waste and one 1 ninetysix 96 gallon cart for the storage of all accepted recycling materials as determined by the public works director except glass and yard waste or other materials as may be determined by the public works director each occupant shall place all solid waste to be collected in the cityprovided sixtyfour 64 gallon container and all recyclable materials in the cityprovided ninetysix 96 gallon container each occupant shall not damage abuse or misuse any container provided by the city and shall keep the area surrounding such container in a clean neat and sanitary condition the city may provide each residential solid waste customer with households consisting of one 1 or two 2 persons with options for sizes smaller than the standard sizes otherwise established in this section   art 1 31510 commercial establishments to provide containers every commercial establishment shall provide sufficient and adequate containers to be approved by the city staff for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste to serve such commercial establishment   art 2 31510 reserved editors note of adopted  repealed  2229 which pertained to residential container specifications and derived from  1314 of the 1967   tree limbs  how collected all tree limbs and brush shall be securely tied in bundles not larger than fortyeight 48 inches long and eighteen 18 inches in diameter the weight of any individual bundle shall not exceed seventyfive 75 pounds    61592 demolition and construction wastes not to be collected demolition and construction wastes shall be collected only by contractual arrangement with the city or by other persons authorized by the city to collect such demolition and construction wastes pursuant to this chapter and must not be disposed of in regularly scheduled residential collections  21589  art 4 31510 reserved editors note of adopted  repealed  2232 which pertained to when containers collected and derived from  1317 of the 1967   collection of solid waste  residential and commercial a every owner or occupant of a residential dwelling unit within the city limits shall receive solid waste collection service and tender payment therefor in accordance with the fees established in this article the owners and occupants of individual premises receiving solid waste collection service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay such fees the city shall have the power to file civil suit against owners occupants or both to recover all sums due and in addition thereto reasonable attorneys fees b it shall be the duty of each commercial establishment to provide for collection of all solid waste produced upon such premises and to dispose of such waste in a lawful manner c all commercial waste and recyclable containers shall be used in such a way as to prevent blowing or spreading of refuse in any way art 1 82018 editors note art 1 adopted aug 20 201 repealed the former  2233 and enacted a new section as set out herein the former  2233 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from   and art 6 adopted  bulky rubbish collected  how all solid waste from premises to which collection services are provided by the city shall be collected except as elsewhere provided in this chapter and except for bulky rubbish provided however that bulky rubbish may be collected according to regulations and charges to be made and promulgated by the city staff as hereinafter provided bulky rubbish shall not be collected upon regular collection days but shall be collected upon request to the city staff and according to procedures established by the city staff nothing in this chapter shall require the city to collect any bulky rubbish that the city staff determines to be harmful to its collection equipment or that cannot be adequately disposed of by the disposal methods utilized by the city   art 1 61791 waste containers  where placed a all residential waste and recyclable containers shall be placed within three 3 feet of the curb or edge of roadway or alley where ordered by the city staff for collection except as elsewhere provided for in this chapter such containers shall be placed at the curb or edge of roadway or alley on or twelve 12 hours prior to the day of collection and removed on the same day within a reasonable time such containers shall be used in such a way as to prevent blowing or spreading of refuse in any way and be stored on private property b all commercial waste containers shall be placed upon private property accessible for collection and in a welldrained area c the contents of residential waste containers shall be kept in such condition that they can at all times be readily and fully removable by the city art 2 82018 editors note art 2 adopted aug 20 201 repealed the former  2235 and enacted a new section as set out herein the former  2235 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from   art 2 adopted    adopted   and art 7 adopted  collection frequency all residential solid wastes shall be collected at least twice weekly once for regular trash collection and once for collection of recyclable materials on the days designated and in the manner required by the public works director to meet the objectives of the citys solid waste management plan    61592 collection vehicles  condition all collection vehicles shall be maintained in a safe clean and sanitary condition and shall be so constructed maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom all vehicles used for collection of solid waste shall be constructed with watertight bodies and with covers which shall be an integral part of the vehicle or shall be a separate cover of suitable material with fasteners designed to secure all sides of the cover to the vehicle and shall be secured whenever the vehicle is transporting solid waste or as an alternate the entire bodies thereof shall be enclosed with only loading hoppers exposed no solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers before any permit for the collection of solid wastes shall be issued the city staff shall inspect and approve applicants equipment according to this section if the applicants equipment shall not meet these requirements the permit shall not be issued    21589 disposal of rock and earth no permits of any kind shall be required for the removal hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities  however all such material shall be conveyed in vehicles so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rightsofway transportation and disposal of demolition and construction wastes shall be in accordance with later sections  disposal of waste  fee a solid waste shall be disposed of at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city and shall comply with the requirement of the state department of natural resources the city may classify certain wastes as hazardous and shall order disposal in a manner which will meet all local state and federal regulations b haulers who dispose of less than twenty 20 tons of solid waste per week at the city disposal facility shall pay a rate of sixtytwo dollars $6200 per ton plus fuel surcharge if applicable the applicable fee shall be increased by twentyfive dollars $2500 for each load that is not properly covered or secured in accordance with state and local law private haulers who regularly use the disposal facility and who regularly dispose of more than twenty 20 tons of solid waste per week at the city disposal facility shall have a rate established by contract based on the operating costs the charge per ton will be increased when the previous months average per gallon diesel fuel price exceeds three dollars and seventyfive cents $375 the charge per ton will be increased by one hundred percent 100% of the difference between the previous months average per gallon diesel fuel price and three dollars and seventyfive cents $375 all surcharges will be rounded up to the next cent average per gallon diesel fuel costs will be the average of the midwest region index as published by the u s department of energy c fuel surcharge the monthly solid waste collection fee for residential customers shall be increased when the previous months average per gallon diesel fuel price exceeds three dollars and seventyfive cents $375 the charge will be increased by twentyfive 25 percent of the difference between the previous months average per gallon diesel fuel price and three dollars and seventyfive cents $375 all surcharges will be rounded up to the next cent average per gallon diesel fuel costs will be the average of the midwest region index as published by the us department of energy    21589  art 3 61791   61592  art 3 6793 1 62016  art 1 61917  art 1 61818 permitrequired no person shall engage in the business of collecting transporting processing or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the city without first obtaining an annual permit therefor from the city  provided however that this provision shall not be deemed to apply to employees of the holder of any such permit collection vehicles of persons holding permits shall have their names addresses and permit numbers painted on both sides of such vehicles in letters of at least three 3 inches in a contrasting color to that of the vehicle  sameliability insurance necessary no permit required by section 2240 shall be issued until and unless the applicant therefor in addition to other requirements set forth shall file and maintain with the city staff a certificate of insurance covering all operations of such applicant pertaining to such business and all vehicles to be operated in the conduct thereof in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars $10000000 for each person injured or killed and in the amount of not less than eight hundred thousand dollars $80000000 in the event of injury or death of two 2 or more persons in any single accident and in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars $10000000 for damage to property should such policy be cancelled the city staff shall be notified of such cancellation by the insurance carrier in writing not less than ten 10 days prior to the effective date of such cancellation and provisions to that effect shall be incorporated in any such policy which shall also place upon the company writing such policy the duty to give such notice  21589 sameinformation required each applicant for any permit required by section 2240 shall state in his application therefor 1 the nature of the permit desired as to collect transport process or dispose of solid waste or any combination thereof  2 the characteristics of solid waste to be collected transported processed or disposed  3 the number of solid waste vehicles to be operated thereunder  4 the precise location of solid waste processing or disposal facilities to be used  5 boundaries of the collection area  and 6 such other information as required by the city staff  samewhen issued a if the application for a license required by section 2240 shows that the applicant will collect transport process or dispose of solid wastes without hazard to the public health or damage to the environment and in conformity with the laws of the state and this article the city staff shall issue the permit authorized by this article the permit shall be issued for a period of one 1 year and each applicant shall pay therefor a fee of forty dollars $4000 if in the opinion of the city staff modifications can be made to the application regarding service equipment or mode of operation so as to bring the application within the intent of this article  the city may notify the applicant in writing setting forth the modification to be made and the time in which it shall be done b if the applicant fails to meet all conditions he shall be notified in writing that the permit applied for was denied the annual permit may be renewed upon payment of fees except where modifications in the applicants business have occurred if modifications have occurred then the applicant must reapply    21589  art 8 31510  art 10 102113 inspection in order to insure compliance with the laws of this state this article and the rules and regulations authorized herein the city staff is authorized to inspect all phases of solid waste management within the city violations shall be reported to the city manager and may be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the permit depending upon the circumstances involved nothing in this section shall be construed to in any way limit amend or alter any provisions in the public nuisance ordinances of the city  rules and regulations a the city staff shall make amend revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary rules and regulations governing but not limited to 1 preparation drainage and wrapping of garbage deposited in solid waste containers 2 specifications for solid waste containers including the type composition equipment size and shape thereof 3 identification of solid waste containers and of the covers thereof and of equipment thereto appertaining if any 4 weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers and the contents thereof and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid waste too large for solid waste containers 5 storage of solid waste in solid waste containers 6 sanitation maintenance and replacement of solid waste containers 7 schedules of and routes for collection of solid waste 8 collection points of solid waste containers 9 collection and disposal of solid waste 10 processing facilities and fees for the use thereof 11 disposal facilities and fees for the use thereof 12 records of quantity and type of wastes received at processing andor disposal facilities 13 handling of special wastes such as toxic wastes sludges ashes agriculture construction bulky items tires automobiles oils greases etc b the city collector is hereby authorized to make and promulgate reasonable and necessary rules and regulations for the billing and collection of solid waste collection andor disposal service charges as hereinafter provided for  prohibited practices it shall be unlawful for any person to 1 deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own without the written consent of the owner of such container andor with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge hereinafter provided for solid waste collection and disposal 2 interference in any manner with solid waste collection equipment or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such whether such equipment or collectors shall be those of the city or those of a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city 3 burn solid waste unless an approved incinerator is provided or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control agency 4 dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not approved by the city and the state department of health 5 engage in the business of collecting transporting processing or disposing of solid waste within the city limits of the city without a permit from the city or operate under any expired permit or operate after a permit has been suspended or revoked  residential solid waste collection fees a basic monthly charge the basic monthly solid waste collection fee for residential customers shall be twenty dollars and seventyfive cents $2075 per month per dwelling unit residential back door service may be provided on a contract basis subject to fees based on the additional operating costs associated with providing such service such basic charge shall include the following services 1 collection of all waste or recycling in the cityprovided containers 2 bulk waste collection program 3 fall leaf collection program b additional container customers who receive a second sixtyfour 64 gallon container for solid waste storage and collection shall pay an additional twenty dollars and seventyfive cents $2075 per month per dwelling unit plus the basic monthly charge established in this section c fuel surcharge the monthly solid waste collection fee for residential customers shall be increased when the previous months average per gallon diesel fuel price exceeds three dollars and seventyfive cents $375 the charge will be increased by twentyfive 25 percent of the difference between the previous months average per gallon diesel fuel price and three dollars and seventyfive cents $375 all surcharges will be rounded up to the next cent average per gallon diesel fuel costs will be the u s average as published by the us energy information administration art 2 61818 editors note art 2 adopted  repealed the former  2247 and enacted a new section as set out herein the former  2247 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from art 2 adopted  billing  payment  delinquency  penalty a the city finance director or such other officer or representative of the city as may be designated from time to time shall be responsible for calculating the amount of and rendering bills for the fees established in this article b all service bills shall be due and payable in full fourteen 14 days from the date the bill was rendered and shall be considered delinquent after twentyone 21 days if the last day for remittance falls upon a weekend or holiday or any other day when the offices of the department regularly used for the payment of customer bills are not open to the general public the final payment date shall be extended the close of the next business day the date of payment for remittance mail shall be the date on which the department receives the remittance all accounts which become delinquent shall be charged a ten 10 percent penalty    9 61592  art 1 91994 termination of solid waste collection service in the event an account declared delinquent has not been paid in full within one 1 month of the initial due date the city may terminate solid waste collection service to such premises  failure to pay fees  penalty it shall be unlawful for any person properly charged for fees established in this article to fail to pay such fees and such offense shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars $50000  penalties except as otherwise provided in this article any person violating any of the provisions of this article or any lawful rules or regulations promulgated pursuant thereto upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars $500 nor more than five hundred dollars $50000  provided that each days violation thereof shall be a separate offense for the purpose hereof  dumpster a general because the unregulated maintenance and operation of dumpsters in residential lots containing three 3 or fewer dwelling units and in the city rightsofway presents a threat to the public health safety environment and general welfare no person business or any other entity shall operate keep store or maintain a dumpster on a residential lot containing three 3 or fewer dwelling units or in the city rightofway without first obtaining the dumpster permit required by this chapter and shall maintain said dumpster in accordance with said permit this chapter and any regulation promulgated hereunder b permit required no dumpster shall be used in a residential lot containing three 3 or fewer dwelling units or in the city rightsofway without first obtaining a permit from the city manager or hisher designee if a dumpster is to be located upon a public way then an onstreet dumpster permit must be obtained if a dumpster is to be located in a residential lot containing three 3 or fewer dwelling units then a residential dumpster permit must be obtained if the city manager or hisher designee determines that a submitted dumpster permit application is accurate and adequate to keep the site free from debris refuse trash solid waste or like material that is injurious to the public health safety and environment the city manager or hisher designee may issue a permit for the dumpster performance of the activities scheduled in the dumpster permit shall be a condition of the permit and nonperformance of the activities scheduled in the dumpster permit shall be a violation of the permit and conditions of this chapter c onstreet dumpster permit dumpster may initially be placed on the public rightofway for a maximum of two 2 weeks an extension may be requested for a valid reason for a period of one 1 week all dumpsters placed on the public rightofway shall have sufficient reflective markings to be visible after nightfall d residential dumpster permit dumpster may initially be placed on the residential lot containing three 3 or fewer dwelling units for a maximum of thirty 30 days an extension may be requested for a valid reason for a period of thirty 30 days all dumpsters placed on lots containing three 3 or fewer dwelling units shall be maintained and serviced so that refuse does not overflow the resident property owner and the dumpster company are all responsible persons under this section art 2 32017 secs 22532270  reserved article iii  litter footnotes  2  cross reference throwing injurious refuse on streets  2411 state law reference solid waste disposal rsmo   et seq title this article shall be known and may be cited as the cape girardeau antilitter a1 penalties for violation any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars $50000 or be not less than one hundred twentyfive dollars $12500 and imprisoned in the city jail for a period not exceeding three 3 months or by both such fine and imprisonment each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue may constitute a separate offense and may be punishable as such hereunder a2  art 5 12213 definitions for the purpose of this article the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein accumulated litter means litter of an amount and degree so as to constitute a nuisance aircraft means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air the word aircraft shall include helicopters and lighterthanair dirigibles and balloons garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling preparation and cooking and consumption of food handbill means any printed or written matter any sample or device dodger circular leaflet pamphlet newspaper magazine paper booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature litter means garbage refuse and rubbish and all other waste material which if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited tends to create a danger to public health safety and welfare newspaper means a publication of general circulation printed distributed and subscribed to by the recipient which contains either news opinions advertisements or other items of general interest and in addition thereto shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four 4 issues per year and sold to the public park means a park reservation playground beach recreation center or any other public area in the city owned andor used by the city and developed to active or passive recreation private premises means any dwelling house building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private purposes whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant and shall include any yard grounds walk driveway porch steps vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling house building or other structure public place means any and all streets sidewalks boulevards alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks squares spaces grounds and buildings receptacle means a litter storage and collection container constructed and maintained so as to prevent litter from escaping therefrom and which is offered for the purpose of receiving litter refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes including garbage rubbish ashes street cleanings dead animals abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes such as paper wrappings cigarettes cardboard tin cans yard clippings leaves wood glass bedding crockery and similar materials vehicle means every device in upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks a3 litter in public places no person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street sidewalk or other public place within the city except in receptacles or in an official city dump a4 placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering persons placing litter in receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street sidewalk or other public place or upon private property a5 sweeping litter into gutters prohibited no person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway a6 litter thrown by persons in vehicles no person while a driver or passenger in a vehicle shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city or upon private property a7 cross reference traffic ch 26 truck loads causing litter a no person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded so as to prevent any load contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street alley or other public place or upon private property in an amount so as to constitute a nuisance unless the person removes such load contents or litter from said street alley public or private place at the completion of the working day or at least once each calendar working day b no person shall drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street alley or other public place mud dirt sticky substances litter or foreign matter of any kind in an amount so as to constitute a nuisance unless the person removes the mud dirt sticky substances litter or foreign matter from said street alley or public place at the completion of the working day c any person who creates a nuisance on account of violation of section a or b above must abate that nuisance immediately and may not wait until the completion of the working day whenever a duly commissioned police officer of the city determines that such nuisance is an immediate hazard for persons who travel upon said street alley or other public place or said private property if a police officer makes a determination that the nuisance constitutes an immediate hazard he may order the responsible person to begin immediate cleanup and abatement of the nuisance and should such person fail or refuse to comply with the police officers order the city shall have the right and authority to proceed to correct and remove said immediate hazard and charge the expense thereof to the person who is in violation of section a or b  above a8  art 1 81792 litter in parks no person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place or upon private property where receptacles are not provided all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein a9 cross reference parks and recreation ch 18 litter in lakes and fountains no person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain pond lake stream bay or other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city a10 throwing or distributing handbills in public places no person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any sidewalk street or other public place within the city  provided however that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk street or other public place within the city for a person to hand out or distribute a handbill to any person willing to accept it a11 cross reference licenses and business regulations ch 15 reserved editors note of adopted nov 5 201 repealed  2282 placing handbills on or in vehicles which derived from  16a12 of the 1967   depositing handbill on uninhabited or vacant premises no person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant a13 prohibiting distributing of handbills where property posted no person shall throw deposit or distribute any handbill upon any private premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words no trespassing no peddlers or agents no advertisement or any similar notice advising that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed or to have any handbills left upon such premises a14 distributing handbills at private premises a no person shall throw deposit leave or distribute any handbill in or upon private premises except by handing or transmitting such handbill directly to the owner occupant or other person then present in or upon such private premises  provided however that in case of private premises which are not posted as provided in section 2284 such person may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such private premises if such handbill is so placed or deposited in a receptacle specifically designed to receive the same  this proviso shall not be interpreted to authorize the placing of handbills under or behind screens or entrance doors on porches in yards or in mailboxes when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations b the provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the united states nor to newspapers as defined herein except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street sidewalk or other public place or upon private property a15 dropping litter from aircraft no person in an aircraft shall throw out drop or deposit within the city any litter handbill or any other object a16 cross reference airport ch 4 posting notices prohibited no person shall post or affix any notice poster or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public to any lamppost street sign traffic control device public utility pole or public tree or upon any private structure or building except as may be required by law or authorized in writing by the city manager a17  art 1 9799  art 1 5503 litter on occupied private property no person shall throw or deposit litter on any private property within the city whether owned by such person or not  provided however that this section shall not prohibit the deposit or storage of litter in receptacles for collection a18 owner of business to maintain premises free of litter the owner or person in control of a business shall maintain the property in such a manner that litter which is a result of his business operation will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street sidewalk or other public place or upon any other private property owners or persons in control of a business shall keep their premises free from litter by picking up the litter at regular intervals and depositing this litter into receptacles a regular interval shall be whatever period that is necessary to keep litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street sidewalk or other public place or upon any other property but shall be not less than twice a day provided however that this section shall not apply to the owner or operator of the business who at reasonable intervals collects and removes such litter which has been carried or deposited by the elements upon a street sidewalk or other public place or upon private property a19 cross reference licenses and business regulations ch 15 throwing depositing rock metal glass wood etc upon private premises of another or upon public property  penalty no person shall throw or deposit in or upon another persons private premises or a public place litter which consists in whole or in part of rock metal glass wood masonry hard plastic or other similar hard substances notwithstanding section 2272 each violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars $10000 and not more than five hundred dollars $50000 or by imprisonment not exceeding three 3 months or by both such fine and imprisonment a20 owner to maintain premises free of litter the owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter provided however that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in receptacles for collection a21 control of runoff water  penalty a it shall be unlawful for any person to fail neglect or refuse to control the runoff of water from land possessed by him or under his management or control so that soil dirt gravel rock sand trash filth or similar material in an amount so as to constitute a nuisance is carried upon a public sidewalk street or alley or into publicly maintained drains or drainways b any person who creates a nuisance on account of violation of section a above must abate that nuisance immediately whenever a duly commissioned police officer of the city determines that such nuisance is an immediate hazard for persons who travel upon said street alley or sidewalk or to the proper functioning of the drain or drainway if a police officer makes that determination he may order the responsible person to begin immediate cleanup and abatement of the nuisance and should such person fail or refuse to comply with such police officers order the city shall have the right and authority to proceed to correct and remove said immediate hazard and charge the expense thereof to the person who is in violation of section a above c a person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars $10000 per day nor in excess of five hundred dollars $50000 per day for each day of such violation each and every day a person fails to abate such nuisance shall constitute a separate offense art 1 101695 removal of mud dirt etc from public streets  penalty a any person firm or corporation to whom a building demolition grading stormwater or floodplain permit has been issued shall remove at least twice each working day any mud dirt sticky substance litter or foreign matter of any kind carried into or deposited upon any public street public sidewalk or other public way or place of the city by any vehicle or by the wheels of any vehicle entering or leaving the site of the project for which the building demolition grading stormwater or floodplain permit was issued the removal shall be performed once prior to noon and once at the end of the working day b any landowner involved in building construction demolition or grading shall remove at least twice each working day any mud dirt sticky substance litter or foreign matter of any kind carried into or deposited upon any public street public sidewalk or other public way or place of the city by any vehicle or by the wheels of any vehicle entering or leaving the site of the project of the building construction demolition or grading the removal shall be performed once prior to noon and once at the end of the working day c if any person firm or corporation referred to in sections a or b above shall fail or refuse to remove said mud dirt sticky substance litter or foreign matter within the times set forth hereinabove or when ordered to do so by a duly commissioned police officer of this city the city shall have the right and authority to proceed to remove such substances and charge the expense thereof to such person firm or corporation d a person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars $10000 per day nor in excess of five hundred dollars $50000 per day for each day of such violation each and every day a person fails to remove such substance shall constitute a separate offense art 1 101695 secs 229422110  reserved article iv  weeds footnotes  3  cross reference nuisances  1331 et seq state law reference authority of city to remove weeds and other nuisances rsmo    excessive growth prohibited a it shall be unlawful for the owner of any property in the city or any lessee or any occupant having control of such property to allow any growth of weeds grass or poisonous or harmful vegetation a greater height than ten 10 inches on the average within two hundred 200 feet of any building or one hundred 100 feet of any improved street or any accumulation of dead weeds grass or brush within two hundred 200 feet of any building or one hundred 100 feet of any improved street whenever such private property abuts a public rightofway or easement belonging to the city of cape girardeau or any public entity and there exists in such rightofway or easement a tree lawn or grassy area between the private property line and the midline of said rightofway or easement then such tree lawn or grassy area shall be considered for purposes of this section requiring cutting of grass or weeds to be a part of the private lot which abuts the rightofway or easement and it shall be the duty of those responsible under this section for the maintenance of the private lot to equally maintain the tree lawn or grassy area within the abutting rightofway or easement and all of the provisions of this section shall apply with equal force and effect to said tree lawn or grassy area b penalty any person convicted of violating section 22111 shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars $50000 or by imprisonment not exceeding three 3 months or by both such fine and imprisonment c the provisions as contained herein shall not be the exclusive remedy available to the city for enforcement of the public policy prohibiting excessive weed and vegetation growth and the city may pursue any additional remedies it may have as provided by law or elsewhere in this ordinances including but not limited to the provisions of of this ordinances d each day any person remains in violation of section 22111 hereof constitutes a separate offense for the purpose of prosecution in municipal court    72092  art 1 2204  art 1 1410 secs 22112 22113  reserved editors note of adopted  repealed  22112 and  22113 in their entirety
